'''Love''' is any of a number of [[emotion]]s and [[experience]]s related to a sense of strong [[affection]] or profound [[oneness (concept)|oneness]].<ref name="oxford"/> Depending on the context, ''love'' can embody a wide variety of intended meanings. It is commonly conceived of [[romantic love|romantically]], as a deep, [[ineffability|ineffable]] [[feeling]] of intense and tender [[interpersonal attraction|attraction]]<ref name="dic">http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/love</ref>. It is shared in passionate or [[intimacy|intimate]] [[interpersonal relationship|interpersonal]] and [[human sexuality|sexual]] relationships. The romantic dimension of love may also be extended or refined<ref name="PlatonicSchool">{{cite book
+
'''Love''' is any of a number of [[emotion]]s and [[experience]]s related to a sense of strong [[affection]] or profound [[oneness (concept)|oneness]].<ref name="oxford"/> Depending on context, ''love'' can have a wide variety of intended meanings. It is commonly conceived of [[romantic love|romantically]], as a deep, [[ineffability|ineffable]] [[feeling]] of intense and tender [[interpersonal attraction|attraction]] shared in passionate or [[intimacy|intimate]] [[interpersonal relationship|interpersonal]] and [[human sexuality|sexual]] relationships.<ref name="dic">http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/love</ref> Love can also be conceived of as [[Platonic love]],<ref name="PlatonicSchool">{{cite book |last=Kristeller |first=Paul Oskar |title=Renaissance Thought and the Arts: collected essays |publisher=Princeton University |year=1980 |id=ISBN 0691020108}}</ref> [[love (religious views)|religious love]],<ref name="Gita">{{cite book |last= Mascaró |first=Juan |title=The Bhagavad Gita |publisher=Penguin Classics |year=2003 |id= ISBN 0140449183}}(J. Mascaró translator)</ref> [[familial love]], and, more casually, anything considered strongly pleasurable, desirable, or preferred, including activities and foods.<ref name="IdiomNote">Casual application of the word ''love'' also includes [[idiom]]atic expressions and uses with differing connotations. For example, as a sardonic expression of disapproval: "I just love how politicians always make empty promises."</ref><ref name="dic"/> This diverse range of meanings in the singular word ''love'' is often contrasted with the plurality of [[Greek words for love|Greek words for ''love'']], reflecting the concept's depth, versatility, and complexity.

Mascaró translator)</ref> [[familial love]], and, more casually, anything considered strongly pleasurable, desirable, or preferred; including activities and foods.<ref name="IdiomNote">Casual application of the word ''love'' also includes [[idiom]]atic expressions and uses with differing connotations. For example, as a sardonic expression of disapproval: "I just love how politicians always make empty promises."</ref><ref name="dic"/> This diverse range of meanings in the singular word ''love'' is often contrasted with the plurality of [[Greek words for love|Greek words for ''love'']], reflecting the concept's depth, versatility, and complexity.
